G.L. c. 209C, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, ��������������������������������������������������������������������������������� (modification of judgments concerning custody and visitation), G.L. c. 209C, ��������������������������������������������������������������������������������������

G.L. c. 215, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������ (modification of judgments concerning custody and visitation), G.L. c. 209C, �����������������������������������������������

G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child, the Court considers all relevant factors, including the childs age, developmental needs, the stability and quality of each parents home environment, the childs relationship with each parent, and the willingness of each parent to foster the childs relationship with the other parent.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time matters concerning the Child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, ����������������������������������� and controlling case law, including *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the Probate and Family Court’s continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time matters under G.L. c. 208 and related case law. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas addresses standards for awarding custody and permitting removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, §§ 30–31, but it does not discuss or establish any rule about the court’s ongoing or continuing jurisdiction post-judgment. Therefore, it does not support the specific jurisdictional proposition for which it is cited.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815).”}

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time matters concerning the Child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, ���������������������������������� and controlling case law, including *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the court’s *continuing jurisdiction* over custody and parenting‑time matters under G.L. c. 208 and related case law. Rosenthal v. Maney deals with standards for modifying custody (material and substantial change under § 28) and removal under § 30, but it does not discuss or ground any holding in the court’s continuing jurisdiction, nor in the idea that jurisdiction persists pursuant to § 208 and the cited authorities. The only discussion touching jurisdiction is historical dicta in a footnote explaining that § 30 was once considered ancillary to continuing jurisdiction, without using that as a present basis for decision.

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment; and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: This opinion is primarily a removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and a child support modification case. While it involves complaints for modification, it does not articulate the general Massachusetts standard that custody or parenting-time orders may be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances plus best interests of the child. The only explicit modification standard discussed concerns child support (inconsistency with the Child Support Guidelines), not custody/parenting time, so it does not support the proposition claimed.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “In support of his complaint for modification, the father alleged as a material and substantial change of circumstances the mother’s remarriage. … General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 2011, c. 93, § 37, provides that a child support order shall be modified ‘if there is an inconsistency between the amount of the existing order and the amount that would result from application of the child support guidelines.’ Although the father alleged that there had been a material change of circumstances, the judge here was correct to apply those guidelines to the parties’ updated financial circumstances.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 182\t.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment; and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 182\t.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a removal (relocation) dispute under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulates a child-focused ‘best interests’ standard in the context of joint physical custody. It does not set out or apply the general Massachusetts standard for modification of custody or parenting-time orders as requiring (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment and (2) that modification be in the child’s best interests. The only mention of ‘substantial change in circumstances’ appears in a quoted ALI Principles provision on relocation, not as a statement of Massachusetts modification law, so this case does not support the claimed proposition.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 182\t.relevant_excerpt: The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: “(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] . . . . (4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ...”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\t4.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child, the Court considers all relevant factors, including the childs age, developmental needs, the stability and quality of each parents home environment, the childs relationship with each parent, and the willingness of each parent to foster the childs relationship with the other parent.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\t4.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely reaffirms that custody decisions must be based on the child’s best interests and states that a court must weigh “all relevant factors” in doing so. It also emphasizes stability and continuity, each parent’s caregiving role, and the parents’ ability to foster the child’s relationships. However, the case does not itself lay out the specific multi-factor list in the proposition (age, developmental needs, etc.) in that precise formulation, so it supports the general best‑interests, all‑relevant‑factors principle rather than that exact catalog of factors.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\t4.relevant_excerpt: “‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge . . . [whose] findings in a custody case ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’’ … However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’” (Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845, quoting Rosenberg v. Merida).

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\t.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child, the Court considers all relevant factors, including the childs age, developmental needs, the stability and quality of each parents home environment, the childs relationship with each parent, and the willingness of each parent to foster the childs relationship with the other parent.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\t.support_reasoning: The court extensively applies the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and notes the judge may consider a wide range of factors, such as stability, developmental needs, sibling relationships, and home environment. However, it does not set out or endorse the specific multifactor list stated in the proposition, nor does it mention the parents’ willingness to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent. The opinion supports a broad, flexible best‑interests inquiry, but not the particular, enumerated test described in the proposition.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\t.relevant_excerpt: “When the choice is between two caretakers, each of whom seeks to be the substitute for the child’s biological parents, a judge may consider a wide range of permissible evidence in determining which placement will serve the child’s best interests. In some cases, the importance of leaving a child in the home of his substitute caretaker may be the most important determining factor. In others, there may be evidence that pulls in a different direction. It is for the trial judge to determine the weight of the evidence; we do not require that any evidence be established with exceptional force.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.proposition: The preferences and expressed wishes of a mature child are factors that the Court may consider in assessing the childs best interests, although such preferences are not controlling.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that the preference of an eleven-year-old child is a factor to be considered but is not given decisive (controlling) weight. The court cites prior Massachusetts cases for this principle and applies it to Vaughn’s expressed wishes, treating them as relevant but not determinative of the best interests analysis. This directly aligns with the claimed proposition about mature child preferences in custody determinations.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.relevant_excerpt: “Although the boy was described in testimony as ‘a really bright student,’ we note that the preference of an eleven-year-old is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered. See Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602 (1981); Baird v. Attorney Gen., 371 Mass. 741, 753 (1977); Bellotti v. Baird, 443 U.S. 622 (1979); Stone v. Duffy, 219 Mass. 178, 182 (1914); Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 617 (1987).”

*Jones v. Jones*, 349 Mass. 259, 264 (19.proposition: The preferences and expressed wishes of a mature child are factors that the Court may consider in assessing the childs best interests, although such preferences are not controlling.
*Jones v. Jones*, 349 Mass. 259, 264 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion never discusses the child’s own preferences or wishes as a factor in the custody determination. The court’s analysis focuses on the mother’s conduct, stability, and opportunities to see the child, and on the grandparents’ and father’s ability to care for the child, all under the general ‘welfare of the child’ standard. There is no indication that the child’s expressed desires were considered, let alone treated as a non‑controlling factor, so this case does not support the specific proposition cited.
*Jones v. Jones*, 349 Mass. 259, 264 (19.relevant_excerpt: “We concur in the conclusion of the judge that the ‘happiness and welfare of Wendolyn require that she be in the custody of … Elsa.’ ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … The uprooting of a child of tender years in these circumstances should be done only for compelling reasons.”

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.proposition: Where material changes in the parents circumstances alter their respective abilities to meet the childs needs or to provide an appropriate home and schedule, modification of prior custodial arrangements may be warranted.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.support_reasoning: The case concerns modification of alimony and child support, not modification of custodial arrangements. The court discusses when a material change in circumstances (income, assets, employment) may justify changing support obligations and expressly applies G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 37 in that context. It does not address custody, parental ability to provide an appropriate home or schedule, or standards for modifying custodial orders, so it does not support the specific custody-related proposition.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28…. The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”

*Champion v. Champion*, 54 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Where material changes in the parents circumstances alter their respective abilities to meet the childs needs or to provide an appropriate home and schedule, modification of prior custodial arrangements may be warranted.
*Champion v. Champion*, 54 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion deals almost entirely with property division, valuation of a sole proprietorship, support, and a later request to modify alimony based on the wife’s disability and financial circumstances. While it applies the general "material change in circumstances" standard for modification of support, it does not address modification of *custodial* arrangements, nor does it discuss changes in the parents’ respective abilities to provide an appropriate home or schedule as a basis for changing custody. The cited case therefore does not support the specific proposition about modification of prior custodial arrangements.
*Champion v. Champion*, 54 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). The determination of the extent and palpability of such change, however, lies in large measure within the discretion of the trial judge.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Where material changes in the parents circumstances alter their respective abilities to meet the childs needs or to provide an appropriate home and schedule, modification of prior custodial arrangements may be warranted.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the governing standard for custody determinations—namely, the child’s welfare and best interests—and criticizes the trial judge for not applying those criteria. It does not discuss modification of existing custodial arrangements based on material changes in the parents’ circumstances, nor does it articulate a rule about changed circumstances altering parents’ relative abilities to meet the child’s needs. The cited case is therefore about the correct criteria for an initial or current custody award, not about when modification is warranted due to changed conditions.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: Massachusetts law encourages parents to foster and support the childs relationship with the other parent; failure or refusal to do so is relevant to the best-interests analysis.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes that Massachusetts law values a child’s frequent and continuing contact with both parents and ties that principle directly into the “best interests” analysis. It cites Felton v. Felton for the proposition that the law sees value in such contact and notes that, when parents are at odds, the child’s best interests may justify limiting one parent’s liberties. This shows that supporting or undermining the child’s relationship with the other parent is a relevant best‑interests consideration, even though the case ultimately upholds a reduction in the father’s visitation.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process and in the major decisions that attach thereto. We agree with the precept that ‘the law sees a value in “frequent and continuing contact” of the child[ren] with both . . . parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 234, quoting from In re Marriage of Murga, 103 Cal. App. 3d 498, 503 (1980)… ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’”}
